clinical_validity.gcep: Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel

generif.text: A novel, widely expressed zinc-finger (plant homeodomain[PHD]-like finger) gene had 8 different missense and truncation mutations in 7 familial and 2 sporadic cases of BFLS (p. 661).
...mutations within a novel widely expressed zinc-finger gene (PHF6) have been described in nine families with Borjesson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome... p. 1208
The gene, PHF6, implicated in the Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome has recently been identified. p. 1295

A study of 9 families with PHF6 muations revealed that the phenotype is milder and more variable than previously described and evolves with age; seven missense mutations and two truncation mutations were identifed
By finding a PHF-6 mutation in a family with Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome it was speculated that there is a mutational hot spot in the gene.
novel mutation results in exon skipping and mild Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome

Success of PHF6 screening in males suspected of having Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome is markedly increased if there is a positive family history and/or skewed X-inactivation is found in the mother.
we describe a novel mutation that changes a residue within the first plant homeodomain zinc finger motif of PHF6 in a family with classical features of Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome

these results identify PHF6 as a new X-linked tumor suppressor in T-ALL and point to a strong genetic interaction between PHF6 loss and aberrant expression of TLX transcription factors in the pathogenesis of this disease.
Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome (BFLS) may represent a cancer predisposition syndrome and that mutations of PHF6 contribute to T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.
PHF6 as a tumor suppressor gene mutated in acute myeloid leukemias (AML) and extend the role of this X-linked tumor suppressor gene in the pathogenesis of hematologic tumors.
Our data suggest that PHF6 mutation might play a role in tumorigenesis not only of T-cell acute lymphoblatic leukemia, but also acute myelogenous leukemia and hepatocellular carcinoma.
in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, PHF6 mutations are a recurrent genetic abnormality associated with mutations of NOTCH1, JAK1 and rearrangement of SET-NUP214.
PHF6 interacts with the nucleosome remodeling and deacetylation complex and is localized primarily in the nucleoplasm and nucleolus.
Data suggest that mutations of PHF6 are associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) progression.
These results reveal that the key function of PHF6 is involved in regulating rRNA synthesis, which may contribute to its roles in cell cycle control, genomic maintenance, and tumor suppression.

The findings show that de novo mutations in PHF6 in females result in a recognisable phenotype which overlap with Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome but also has additional distinct features, thus adding a new facet to this disorder.
Our report confirms that PHF6 loss in females results in a recognizable phenotype overlapping with Coffin-Siris syndrome and distinct from Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome.
these data support the hypothesis that PHF6 may function as a transcriptional repressor using its ePHD domains binding to the promoter region of its repressed gene
Recurrent microdeletion was detected in Xq26.3, causing loss of PHF6 expression, a potential tumor suppressor gene, and the miR-424, which is involved in the development of acute myeloid leukemia.
The PHF6 tumor suppressor gene was targeted in acute lymphoblastic leukemia by microRNA-128-3p.
Female phenotypes of Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome patients with PHF6 mutations
Our RBBP4-PHF6 complex structure provides insights into the molecular basis of PHF6-NuRD complex interaction and implicates a role for PHF6 in chromatin structure modulation and gene regulation.
Phf6 is a "lineage-specific" cancer gene that plays opposing roles in developmentally distinct hematopoietic malignancies.

Our results suggest that PHF6 may function as an oncogenic factor in several types of cancer. We also hypothesize that PHF6 may also play its role in a tissue-specific manner. Our findings suggest further investigations regarding the exact role of PHF6 in tumor types.
PHF6 localizes to the sub-nucleolar fibrillar center where it binds to rDNA-coding sequences.  PHF6 mediates the overall levels of ribosome biogenesis within a cell.

PHF6 defects most likely result in their loss of function and have a substantial effect on the evolution into the aggressive types of myeloid neoplasms, associated with other concomitant genetic defects including RUNX1 mutations

The mutations of the gene encoding plant homeodomain (PHD)-like finger protein 6 (PHF6) contribute to the pathogenesis of the X-linked intellectual disability disorder Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome.
PHF6 mutations occur at a low frequency in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia in both female and male patients

EZH2 mutations coexisted with mutations of NOTCH1, IL7R, and PHF6 in the two Adult T-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia patients, and they responded poorly to chemotherapy and experienced difficult clinical histories and inferior outcomes
PHF6-mutated MPAL occurred in a younger patient cohort compared with DNMT3A-mutated cases. All 3 MPAL cases with both T- and B-lineage differentiation harbored PHF6 mutations.
PHF6 mutations are early events and drivers of leukemia stem cell activity in the pathogenesis of T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

PHF6 was significantly elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) tissues and positively correlated with TNM stage, differentiation, and lymph node metastasis. Silencing PHF6 significantly inhibited cell proliferation, colony formation, and migration in HCC cells. Furthermore, silencing PHF6 obviously increased E-cadherin and decreased Vimentin expression.

Isothermal titration calorimetry and surface plasmon resonance experiments with PHF6 and full-length Tau (FL-Tau), respectively, indicated that Purpurin interacted with PHF6 predominantly via hydrophobic contacts and displayed a dose-dependent complexation with FL-Tau
PHF6 promotes non-homologous end joining and G2 checkpoint recovery.
Grandparental genotyping enhances exome variant interpretation.
Plant homeodomain finger protein 6 in the regulation of normal and malignant hematopoiesis.
A Novel Missense Variant in PHF6 Gene Causing Borjeson-Forssman-Lehman Syndrome.
Upregulated Plant Homeodomain Finger Protein 6 Promotes Extracellular Matrix Degradation in Intervertebral Disc Degeneration Based on Microarray Analysis.
The chromatin-binding protein PHF6 functions as an E3 ubiquitin ligase of H2BK120 via H2BK12Ac recognition for activation of trophectodermal genes.
Loss of PHF6 leads to aberrant development of human neuron-like cells.
Notoginsenoside R1 induces DNA damage via PHF6 protein to inhibit cervical carcinoma cell proliferation.
Nonleukemic T/B mixed phenotype acute leukemia with PHF6 and NOTCH1 mutations.
Gene body methylation safeguards ribosomal DNA transcription by preventing PHF6-mediated enrichment of repressive histone mark H4K20me3.
LINC00958/miR-3174/PHF6 axis is responsible for triggering proliferation, migration and invasion of endometrial cancer.
Functional mapping of PHF6 complexes in chromatin remodeling, replication dynamics, and DNA repair.
Further characterization of Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome in females due to de novo variants in PHF6.
MiR-1306-5p promotes cell proliferation and inhibits cell apoptosis in acute myeloid leukemia by downregulating PHF6 expression.
The Role of PHF6 in Hematopoiesis and Hematologic Malignancies.
PHF6 mutation is associated with poor outcome in acute myeloid leukaemia.
PHF6 promotes the progression of endometrial carcinoma by increasing cancer cells growth and decreasing T-cell infiltration.
PHF6 recruits BPTF to promote HIF-dependent pathway and progression in YAP-high breast cancer.
Molecular and clinical analyses of PHF6 mutant myeloid neoplasia provide their pathogenesis and therapeutic targeting.
Investigating the physiological role of S199A and S199D mutants of PHF6 protein in T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

BP.term: negative regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II

name: PHD finger protein 6
summary: This gene is a member of the plant homeodomain (PHD)-like finger (PHF) family. It encodes a protein with two PHD-type zinc finger domains, indicating a potential role in transcriptional regulation, that localizes to the nucleolus. Mutations affecting the coding region of this gene or the splicing of the transcript have been associated with Borjeson-Forssman-Lehmann syndrome (BFLS), a disorder characterized by cognitive disability, epilepsy, hypogonadism, hypometabolism, obesity, swelling of subcutaneous tissue of the face, narrow palpebral fissures, and large ears. Alternate splicing results in multiple transcript variants, encoding different isoforms. [provided by RefSeq, Jun 2010].
